raw_text:
Brown outlines third term vision
 
 Gordon Brown has outlined what he thinks should be the key themes of New Labour's next general election bid.
 
 He said ensuring every child in Britain had the best start in life could be a legacy to match the NHS's creation. The chancellor has previously planned the party's election strategy but this time the role will be filled by Alan Milburn - a key ally of Tony Blair. The premier insisted Mr Brown will have a key role in Labour's campaign, and praised his handling of the economy.
 
 Writing in the Guardian newspaper, Mr Brown outlined his view of the direction New Labour should be taking. "As our manifesto and our programme for the coming decade should make clear, Labour's ambition is not simply tackling idleness but delivering full employment; not just attacking ignorance, disease and squalor but promoting lifelong education, good health and sustainable communities." BBC political editor Andrew Marr said that Mr Brown's article was "a warning shot" to Mr Blair not to try and cut him out of the manifesto writing process. "It was, as always, coded and careful... but entirely deliberate," was Mr Marr's assessment. The prime minister was asked about Mr Brown's article and about his election role when he appeared on BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Mr Blair said a decision had yet to be taken over how the election would be run but the chancellor's role would be "central". Mr Blair argued that under New Labour the country had changed for the better and that was "in part" because of Mr Brown's management of the economy. And he pledged childcare would be a "centrepiece" of Labour's manifesto. He also predicted the next general election will be a "tough, tough fight" for New Labour. But the prime minister insisted he did not know what date the poll would take place despite speculation about 5 May. Mr Blair said he was taking "nothing for granted" ahead of the vote - warning that the Tory strategy was to win power via the back door by hinting they were aiming to cut Labour's majority instead of hoping for an outright win.
llama3.2:1b: Gordon Brown outlined New Labour's third term vision, emphasizing the importance of ensuring every child has a good start in life and delivering full employment.
He also emphasized promoting lifelong education, good health, and sustainable communities.

The chancellor will play a key role in Labour's campaign, praised for handling the economy, with Andrew Marr calling his article "a warning shot" to Tony Blair not to try and cut him out of the manifesto writing process.
llama3.2:3b: Gordon Brown has outlined his vision for New Labour's next general election bid, focusing on key themes such as ensuring every child has a good start in life and delivering full employment.
The chancellor will have a central role in the campaign, according to Prime Minister Tony Blair.

Brown wrote in the Guardian newspaper about the direction Labour should be taking, while Blair said he was taking nothing for granted ahead of the election and warned that the Tories would try to win power via backdoor tactics.
gemma2:2b: Gordon Brown outlined his vision for New Labour's next election campaign, focusing on achieving full employment and promoting lifelong education, good health and sustainable communities.
He emphasized these goals as a lasting legacy comparable to the NHS.
Despite outlining his plan, the exact role in the manifesto writing process is still being determined.
Prime Minister Tony Blair confirmed Brown's key involvement and highlighted his successful management of the economy.
Blair also pledged childcare would be a central theme in the Labour manifesto and acknowledged the potential difficulty of the upcoming election.
He expressed caution about speculation regarding an early election date, while stating that he was prepared for any potential shift in power by opponents.
qwen2.5:0.5b: New Labour should aim for full employment, lifelong education, good health and sustainable communities.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Gordon Brown outlines key themes for New Labour's next election, including full employment and lifelong education as a legacy to match the NHS, praising his handling of the economy.
Alan Milburn will replace Chancellor George Osborne as campaign leader.
Brown plans to ensure every child has a good start in life and promote sustainable communities, saying it should be part of Labour's manifesto.
The prime minister pledges childcare will be a centrepiece of the election strategy but remains undecided about polling date for 5 May.
qwen2.5:3b: Gordon Brown has outlined his vision for New Labour’s third term, emphasizing ensuring every child in Britain had the best start in life as a key legacy comparable to the NHS.
The Chancellor previously planned the party’s election strategy but now Alan Milburn will lead it.
Despite this change, Prime Minister Tony Blair insists Brown will play a significant role and praised his economic management.
In a Guardian article, Brown advocated for tackling unemployment alongside education and health improvements.
This stance was seen as a warning to Blair not to exclude Brown from the manifesto process.
Blair defended Brown's contributions, crediting him with improving the country under New Labour, and promised childcare in the election manifesto.
He also predicted it would be a “tough” election for Labour.
Blair refused to confirm an exact polling date but warned against speculation about potential Tory strategies.

smollm:1.7b: The summary should be: Brown outlines third term vision
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Gordon Brown outlined his third-term vision for New Labour, emphasizing the importance of providing equal opportunities for all children in Britain to achieve a successful future.
Alan Milburn will serve as the next prime minister, a key ally to Tony Blair.
Mr. Brown highlighted his role within Labour's campaign and praised his leadership in managing the economy.
He wrote in The Guardian that Labour's ambition should focus on achieving full employment, not just addressing issues like ignorance, disease, or poverty.
Mr. Marr, a BBC political editor, noted Brown's article as a warning shot against cutting Blair out of manifesto writing.
Blair had planned for Mr. Brown to play a central role in the election but was unsure about the exact date for the poll.
Blair also argued that under New Labour, the country has seen positive changes and that his economic management could play a significant role.
tinyllama:1.1b: In his article titled "The key themes to follow in New Labour's next general election bid," Gordon Brown outlined three critical issues that he believed should be at the forefront of the party's campaign: ensuring every child has access to a good start in life, promoting full employment and sustainable communities.
He expressed his belief that these issues could deliver "full employment" and "good health" for the future generations.
Mr Brown also stressed that Labour's ambition was not just tackling idleness but ensuring every individual has access to lifelong education, good healthcare, and sustainable communities.
In addition, Mr Brown warned against trying to cut him out of the manifesto writing process, insisting that he would still be a crucial part of New Labour's election strategy.
The prime minister promised that childcare would be a "centrepiece" of Labour's manifesto, and that they aimed to win the vote through a "tough, tough fight."
However, Mr Blair did not know when exactly the next general election was going to take place.
Despite speculation about 5 May, the prime minister insisted that he had nothing for granted ahead of the poll.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Former British Chancellor and Leader of the Labour Party, Alan Milburn, has now taken over as deputy leader of New Labour.
His role in the party's upcoming election strategy is to ensure that all children have access to the best education possible.
The party plans to invest heavily in schools, encouraging more people to go to college and raise wages for workers.
It also aims to tackle inequality and improve healthcare for everyone.
phi:2.7b: The article discusses Gordon Brown's plan for New Labour's next general election bid, with a focus on his view of ensuring every child in Britain has the best start in life and promoting lifelong education, good health, and sustainable communities.
The article also mentions that Alan Milburn will lead Labour's campaign this time and that Mr Blair intends to have a key role in it.
He praised the chancellor's handling of the economy but warned against Mr Blair cutting him out of the manifesto-writing process.

Mr Brown's article is seen as a "warning shot" to Mr Blair, while the prime minister himself emphasized the centrality of Mr Brown's role in Labour's campaign and how New Labour has improved the country.
Mr Blair promised childcare would be a centerpiece of their manifesto and predicted a tough battle for them.
However, he did not know when the election would take place despite speculation about 5 May.
He advised that the Tories' strategy is to win power by implying they want to cut Labour's majority rather than outrightly winning.
orca-mini:3b: Brown outlines third term vision for New Labour, ensuring every child has the best start in life will be a legacy to match the NHS's creation and wants full employment, lifelong education, good health and sustainable communities.
hermes3:3b: Gordon Brown outlines New Labour's next election strategy, focusing on every child having best start in life as legacy, full employment & lifelong education, good health & sustainable communities.

Alan Milburn will replace Brown as the party's election strategist, while Prime Minister Tony Blair praised Brown's handling of the economy and confirmed his role in Labour's campaign.
The article was seen as a warning shot to Brown, emphasizing his continued involvement in manifesto writing.
Tony Blair also mentioned that childcare would be a central aspect of their manifesto and predicted the upcoming election would be a challenging fight for New Labour.

BBC's Andrew Marr interpreted this as a subtle warning to Blair not to sideline him in manifesto writing.
Blair, speaking on BBC Radio 4, confirmed Brown's importance in the campaign, highlighted childcare as a manifesto priority, and predicted a tough election.
He dismissed speculation about the election date and warned that the Tories aimed to reduce Labour's majority rather than win outright.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Gordon Brown has outlined New Labour's third term vision, emphasizing a "best start in life" for every child and comprehensive lifelong education, healthcare, and sustainable communities.
Chancellor Alan Milburn will lead the party's election strategy, with Prime Minister Tony Blair assuring Mr. Brown's central role in the manifesto writing process.
The prime minister praised Mr. Brown's economic management and pledged childcare as a key manifesto element.
Blair described the next election as a challenging fight for New Labour, warning against Tory tactics to win power incrementally rather than outrightly.
Despite speculation about a May 5 date, Blair stated he takes no victory for granted.
